How to Train Your Dragon 3 was a huge disappointment. I will be unpopular, but let me explain in detail why I didn't like it.
The first 2 films are absolute masterpieces. The characters, the story, the animations ... Everything was just perfect. For the third, therefore, I had enormous expectations. Then, at the end of the film, I was pretty angry about how they developed this story arc. I mean, in short, the ending is wonderful, for sure. it is also very moving. But the beauty ends here. Everything else is just one stretch after another to get to the good ending. it's as if they already knew how the trilogy was going to end, but didn't have the slightest idea how to get there consistently. The villain, Grimmel, is one-dimensional and left me nothing. The animations, of course, are spectacular and are very colorful. But this is not just a movie. It's not just a nice ending. I know I shouldn't make comparisons, but for example Toy Story 3 (which after there is 4 is another matter) not only has a beautiful ending that will have moved everyone, even non-fans, but also a good villain, a articulated and well-structured story, a great evolution of the characters but above all great emotions. Here all this is only in the beautiful ending, but not in the rest of the film, too flat and made to stretch the broth. How to train your dragon 3 had great potential, but unfortunately it did not succeed in its intent.

The 2019 film: How to Train your Dragon Hidden World was astonishingly heartwarming and felt like a true masterpiece, However The general story line felt similar to the previous movie: How to train your dragon 2 that was released in June of 2014. 

The Film is about the Viking leader, Hiccup and his rare Night Fury dragon, Toothless on a Quest to find another Night Fury dragon, and to explore the world to discover new dragons. They discover another Dragon like Toothless however in their search they attract the attention of the powerful and fearsome enemy Grimmel the Grisly. A ruthless dragon hunter who wants to wipe out all dragons. Hiccup and toothless must find the hidden world of Caldera to hide their dragons and keep them safe from Grimmel's wrath. 

The relationships between the characters in the movie were strong and full of emotion. And the acting was fantastic, you could really feel the bond between all the characters. The movie had plenty of funny and dramatic moments over the course of the story. I personally enjoy the animations and the atmospheric environments in the film. And the music in the film was very well composed and added to the mood of film perfectly 

Many Scenes in the movie brought me Joy or sadness. It was full of great moments that made me laugh or smile, as well as some parts that brought a tear to the eye. Although the plot felt kind of similar to the previous movie with them dealing with an enemy who wanted to destroy/control all dragons it was still unique. The ending was both sad and happy which can be a difficult effect to produce in films. 

I highly recommend you watch How to Train you Dragon Hidden World because it was a wonderful experience, and I could watch It repeatedly. It is well worth your time and money. Just be sure to watch the two previous Movies first so you do not spoil anything.

Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) is a slight and scrawny Viking who lives in Berk, a mountainside village where his fierce, machismo father, Stoick (Gerard Butler), is a tribal leader. The boy is apprenticed to Gobber (Craig Ferguson) whose main task is to keep him out of trouble. It's obvious that Stoick doesn't think his son has the stuff to be a real Viking warrior.

The village has been dealing with a "dragon problem" for a long time. These huge fire-breathing beasts periodically descend upon the village to snatch up all the livestock and destroy the crops. The Vikings only have clubs, swords, and spears to fight them off. The village teens go to a special training camp to learn how to kill dragons.

During one dragon attack, Hiccup sneaks out and uses his own specially built weapon against a dragon. He thinks he might have hit it but isn't sure until the next day when he is wandering in the nearby forest and comes upon a young black dragon with green eyes. Hiccup realizes he is injured and can't fly away. What's more, the dragon is scared, just as he is. Hiccup brings some food and much to his surprise, the boy and the beast bond. Hiccup discovers another way of seeing the world through the dragon's eyes. Now his challenge is to convince the other kids in his dragon-fighting class, especially Astrid (America Ferrera), and his father that everything they thought about the dragons is wrong.

Dreamworks ªs High Flying Animated trilogy bows out with its final installment of How To Train Your Dragon Trilogy with the Hidden World. Taking place one year after the events of the last movie Hiccup and Toothless take on their greatest foe yet and the two have to find the hidden world to not only save each other but all of dragon kind as well. And the movie does its best to push that angle for the film but sadly it does not succeed most of the time. Leaving behind a well-meaning movie that while it does hit some its story really well, it does not live up to be the finale or the movie that it needed to be.
	First off the visuals for the movie were absolutely beautiful, it is not as detailed as the second movie but the 3D models in this movie put a bit more emphasis slicker and smoother designs than detailed. That is not to say that the animation at times does not seem life-like, it just goes a slightly different route, and there is nothing wrong with that. Shots like landscape are done beautifully and of course, the dragons in the film look stupendous. Then, of course, there is the flying scenes, scenes of Toothless and Hiccup flying through the clouds are a staple for the series with each movie always topping the other. This one is no different as the ones that are in this movie are superior to the one that has been in any of the other movies, especially between Toothless and the light furry as that one was a work of art. That is another thing that the movie does well, toothless. Our fun little night furry friend is more alive and expressive in this film than he has been in any of the other. He has almost become human, but with all of the cat/dog characteristics that we have come to love over the past 9 years and it is fair to say that all of the best moment in the film are the ones where he is the focus for both the comedic scene and the dramatic ones.
	Unfortunately, the narrative took a hit for this installment, because up until the last ten minutes of the movie, you would not know that this movie is supposed to be a finale it also doesn ªt help that the film has some pacing problems from the get-go. And because of this, It is completely void of all tension. The villain of the story while entertaining, did not do enough to help the film with that problem and on top of that the movie forcefully tries to paint him as some dark version of Hiccup, which on its own is a very neat concept, but didn ªt spend enough time on that notion to truly sell it. Then, of course, there are the other villains that really don ªt matter because they are truly one of the most forgettable and useless characters in the entire franchise. Then there are the supporting cast, in past couple of movies the side characters while interesting are always pushed to the back in order to make room for Hiccup and toothless, here they get a little more time to shine but it is not always for the best, looking at you Snotlout who makes almost every scene he is in very uncomfortable. This is the third movie of the "Dragon" trilogy, and the first one I've reviewed‚Ä¶ but my rating here can be extrapolated to cover the two previous films as well. This is a really great family-film series for all ages, and I highly recommend all three (a word to the wise: this one might be a tad too scary for small kids). You don't have to have seen the first two films to enjoy this movie, but it does help give the story context ‚Äì the movie does not waste time trying to catch you up with what happened in the first two. The prior films follow our hero Hiccup (first as a little kid and second as a teenager) and his efforts to change his Viking culture from one that kills/enslaves dragons to a collaborative culture that embraces them. In this installment, Hiccup and his faithful dragon Toothless are all grown up‚Ä¶ and love is in the air. While Hiccup flirts with his badass (and totally hot) sidekick Astrid, Toothless finds an elusive female Nightfury dragon and is helpless against her feminine wiles. The way their courtship is rendered is just adorable, it's the best part of the film‚Ä¶it's so sweet and funny, it just brought joy to my heart. You know it's good animation when every thought and feeling is clearly expressed without a single word uttered. I was also impressed with the villain in this film, voiced to skeevy perfection by F. Murray Abraham. He is so threatening and malicious I just wanted him to DIE DIE DIE‚Ä¶ and it's not often that a film will inspire such a passionate hatred towards its villain. The themes of these films have matured as the characters have, and this is by far the most serious of the three‚Ä¶ and also the most heartfelt. This film really yanks on your heartstrings but is never manipulative, it's just a really pure story that will resonate with just about anyone (especially pet lovers!). Be warned, the ending is bittersweet and REALLY emotional, I was a total weepy mess. Kudos to the writers for bookending these films with a definitive and satisfying ending that provides full closure to the story. It's clear there will be no more sequels, and I'm glad of that - they have told the full story and they told it well, what more can you ask? This is a worthy finale to a worthy trilogy.

The plot does borrow a lot from the previous two installments, but as they say, if it ain't broke, don't fix it - and again, the emotional element made the Hidden World what it is, a perfect bittersweet end to the unbreakable bond between boy and dragon.

Usually Dreamworks has bad track records when it comes to sequels, and an even worse one when it comes to trilogies. The 2nd one is usually ok, with the occasion of it being better, but then somehow, the 3rd one has to ruin it. This is happily, not the case here. The "Dragons" franchise seems to be the magic one for Dreamworks, with all of them being just as good or better than the first one. This has just as much heart and drama as the first 2, and was surprisingly mature. (I don't mean "inappropriate", it's still a kids' film, but there are themes of letting things go, and growing up, about the same level as "Toy Story 3".) The film's target audience is definitely those of us who were kids when the first one came out, and are now adults. (It's hard to believe that it's been almost 10 years since the first movie!) This film speaks to the ones who are entering adulthood (somewhere in their early to mid 20s). Like I said, kids can still see it, but the ones who will get the most emotional punch from it are the 20s crowd. (Much like Toy Story 3. I'm seeing a pattern here). Don't go in expecting too many funny moments like the typical Dreamworks fare. It still has some, but they are few and far between. This film's main goal is to make you cry bittersweet tears of both happiness and sadness at the same time, and it succeeds tremendously. This is one of the most heartfelt movies Dreamworks has ever done. If this isn't nominated for "Best Animated Film" at the 2020 Oscars, I will be very disappointed.

DreamWorks' How To Train Your Dragon: Hidden World is the best movie of 2019, so far. This movie has something for all ages. It's filled with lots of action, surprises and humor. This full length animation, co-written and directed by Dean DeBlois, is a definite must see! 

Following the format of any great adventure, screenwriters DeBlois and Cressida Cowell, include everything needed to keep the continuity flowing from the first installment of How to Train Your Dragon to this one. In what is supposed to be the last movie of this trilogy, we see Hiccup, now as the spirited ruler of Berk, protector of the dragons and boyfriend of his longtime friend, Astrid. Hiccup discovers that Toothless, his best bud, is not the only Night Fury alive. He learns that danger is coming and that the only option of surviving is to seek out the Dragon Utopia that his late father once spoke of before a hired tyrant named Grimmel finds it first. There's lots of fire, fighting, roaring, funny bits and mushy stuff too, but you have to watch it to find out who gets the best of who. 

Cinematographer, Gil Zimmerman, is terrific at laying out the scenes, which help the viewers understand the story. We get to see how the Vikings really feel about their dragons and what happens when Hiccup finally meets his match. Every moment feeds off the first and excitement is built off of reflections from the first two movies. The production designers and art directors help keep viewers connected to the characters by giving us realistic scenes and sets that capture you with bright lights and strong graphic details. When darkness comes, critical moments become more authentic. When there's action, you can't help but stay focused. Toothless' upgrades and the new, much larger dragons are epic!

Jay Baruchel is super cool as Hiccup, my favorite character. He's grown, has the best dragon ever, is Chief of the Vikings and everyone loves him, except the Night Fury Slayer and those dragon captors. He has crazy friends like Tuffnut & Ruffnut, who keep you laughing throughout the movie. Hidden World is a screen adaptation of the book series by children's author, Cressida Cowell. It sends you on a fun journey with some curious characters with strange outlooks on life. These anthropomorphic characters make you forget that you are actually watching an animation.

Lessons to take with you after seeing this flick are to make good choices and to allow others to do the same thing, even it doesn't benefit you. I give DreamWorks' How to Train Your Dragon: Hidden World 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 3 to 18, as well as adults. It's one film for everybody! I have been looking forward to seeing "How To Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World" for some time now. I love anything to do with dragons and this animated feature series has been an absolute delight. I get completely lost in the golden, green eyes of the Night Fury dragon named "Toothless", and I love how playful he is. The second film, "How To Train Your Dragon 2", is not only one of the best sequels ever made but easily one of the best computer animated movies ever made, too. The viking characters and dragons inhabit such a rich and complicated world and it's easy to get lost in it, but from the first scene of "The Hidden World" it's plain to see that director Dean DeBlois is trying too hard. The opening's foggy setting quickly becomes too complicated for its own good, and too cheeky. It immediately reminded me of the dull opening sequence to "Avengers: Age of Ultron"√¢" another one of those "hey we got everyone together again so let's be silly in a crazy situation"! It's as though it's too comfortable with itself. It's as if the filmmakers think they no longer have to work hard to make us care. Wrong!

One of the strongest aspects of the second "Dragon" film is that it took an appropriate amount of time between key scenes to let the characters simply converse and tell their story. Most computer animated films sprint really fast from one punch line or cute pratfall to the next, and clock in at around 85 minutes. "Dragon 2" was smarter because it's pacing was more realistic, and extra time was given to Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel), his father Stoick (Gerard Butler), and all of his friends so they could assess their situation and form a plan of action. This singular aspect could also be why it was so expensive at the time, too√¢¬¶! But "The Hidden World" doesn't follow suit and sacrifices the awe and wonder (and color) that I have come to expect from this series for abrupt exposition. I wonder if it could have been something more, or something else√¢¬¶.!

Not once did I laugh out loud during "How To Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World". The previous films had me busting a gut, because they struck a perfect balance between levity and drama to make everything more thrilling. While "The Hidden World" completes a larger story not enough time is given throughout its run time to allow additional character development. Hiccup's girlfriend, Astrid (America Ferrara), and he are no further along in their relationship, which is awkward; and Fishlegs (Christopher Mintz-Plasse) has a creepy crush on Hiccup's mother (Cate Blanchett). Eww! The villain named Grimmel (F. Murray Abraham) is a tired rehash of Drago from the second movie only this time he controls his dragon army with potions instead of hypnotism. My real problem with him is that he fails to embody any real threat. He promises to kill Toothless through the entire film (and has at least five clear chances to do so) but instead just tranquilizes him. Not that I wanted him to kill the coolest dragon of them all but what good is a villain to a story if he's not going to follow through on any threat? Drago was truly dark and malevolent but not once did I think anyone was in peril from the sneering Grimmel. 

I think Dreamworks animated films are among the best, especially the "Kung Fu Panda" series, and "The Croods". "The Hidden World" ends on a high enough note to bring things to a proper close but we only get a fleeting glimpse of the titular hidden world, which looks a lot like Pandora from "Avatar". There should have been a LOT more of it instead of one scene because it's jaw-droppingly beautiful. The epilogue sequences are the best scenes in the picture and while they campaign hard for tears they also feel tacked on at the last minute. I know many will disagree with my observations and that's fine. "How to Train Your Dragon" fans should not miss this final chapter, but I found it already running out of gas from the opening moments. I love this series very much and didn't know what was left to reveal about its rich, frozen world of vikings and dragons but "The Hidden World" felt more like "A Missed Opportunity".

Visually stunning, but the story comes off poorly. It is one deus ex machina after another, driving the plot in an attempt to wrap up the trilogy loose ends, but even that doesn't work that well. The result is a rushed mess at times. A lot of questions about the world that these characters live in never got answered, or were written off with a couple of cheap lines. I can appreciate what Dean Deblois was trying to do, aiming for that bittersweet ending, but it came at the sacrifice of a lot of character development, as well as doing a complete 180 on the entire franchise foundations of "the forever friendship" by pitting one form of love against another.

We don't even get to see another Night Fury, which was one of the biggest teases of the franchise. Instead we get a Light Fury, which is NOT a female Night Fury (per the director). It's a different subspecies. That means toothless species is effectively extinct, Night Furies are gone from the world which creates an unnecessary depressing twist.

Even the separation reasons are low effort. We barely are given a reason as to why the Berkians couldn't live in the hidden world. Yes, the dragons there are hostile to humans, but the Berkians don't even try to prove themselves to the dragons. On top of all that, of all the humans in the world, Berkians are the most deserving for having housed, fed, and even had abandoned their way of life and everything they knew, all for their dragons. They even encouraged them to go free, and yet not one of the dragons decide they should take the humans with them to the hidden world. Not even Toothless thinks to try to bring the Berkians; the very character whom the franchise always tried to show as having close to human intelligence.

Hiccup, shining once again as that supportive friend for his best bud, makes the automatic tailfin a second time (first time in Gift of the Night Fury;  Astrid even throws a reference to that animated short by reminding Hiccup that he tried once before and Toothless didn't want it). Toothless can now fly on his own and thus wins the interest of the Light Fury.

Hiccup even saves BOTH Toothless and the Light Fury by having resolved to give up his life for theirs in the last action sequence (and is saved at the last second). Toothless has always been that character to support Hiccup through thick and thin, and it just seems weird that, given everything they've done for each other, he doesn't insist on trying to bring the Berkians, or even come to visit in that 10 year gap. the whole call of the wild is used as an excuse for his character choices and actions, which is a really pitiful disservice to such an incredible character who has always been portrayed as something more than just a beast in the rest of the franchise.

Even further, Toothless is an Alpha who apparently even has the ability to order other dragons to surrender themselves to capture in one of the sequences, it's not a stretch to believe he would have the ability to mediate between humans and dragons in the hidden world. 

Effectively, this ends up leading to a very manufactured ending of drama instead of providing truely convincing, logical reasons for the necessity of their separation. The writing is loaded with a lot of low hanging cliche fruit that makes the movie feel like it is designed around emotional bait instead of a well written finale.
